snippet.textDisplay: if your controller can take 3kWh of solar, make it triple, 3x 10, 24V x 5 = 120V in series, 5A x2 x3 = 30A in parallel, 30x 100W, put the other two rows of panels in foldable wall panels, get a supercapacitor power bank, million cycles, no need to replace over long trips, even if it would take more space and weight

snippet.textDisplay: You should read the venting requirements for your batteries before cutting holes in anything other than the wooden enclosure. Documentation for other batteries (apc) and articles i found online say that normal ventilation for occupied spaces should be sufficient.  People saying this is the wrong application for lead acid batteries are wrong, you just need to make sure you are following the manufacturers recommendations. This also depends on what type of battery this is, but is suspect these are valve regulated lead acid, which i have been running with my cabins solar set up for almost a year with no problems.
snippet.textOriginal: You should read the venting requirements for your batteries before cutting holes in anything other than the wooden enclosure. Documentation for other batteries (apc) and articles i found online say that normal ventilation for occupied spaces should be sufficient.  People saying this is the wrong application for lead acid batteries are wrong, you just need to make sure you are following the manufacturers recommendations. This also depends on what type of battery this is, but is suspect these are valve regulated lead acid, which i have been running with my cabins solar set up for almost a year with no problems.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't know if anyone has mentioned it yet, but inverters get hot, and a fan to move air might help it live longer.  Also, from personal experience, if you route the edges of the wood on the table and benches, it will be more comfortable.  Nice build so far!

snippet.textDisplay: Set up the panels as 2 banks of 24v in parallel, would be 40 amps at 24v into the charge controller, much more spare capacity.  Should use 4D AGM batteries can handle deep discharge and vibration much better.  Table needs to be 2 layers of plywood on 2 posts.  You should be able to setup the Cummins Onan gen wth auto start for when the batteries run down.  Victron equipment is the only stuff to use, can combine the alternator, solar and generator into 1 system.  Good one booyyyzzz!
snippet.textOriginal: Set up the panels as 2 banks of 24v in parallel, would be 40 amps at 24v into the charge controller, much more spare capacity.  Should use 4D AGM batteries can handle deep discharge and vibration much better.  Table needs to be 2 layers of plywood on 2 posts.  You should be able to setup the Cummins Onan gen wth auto start for when the batteries run down.  Victron equipment is the only stuff to use, can combine the alternator, solar and generator into 1 system.  Good one booyyyzzz!

snippet.textDisplay: Get quartz countertop...stain resistant.  RVs & Trailers use it, so why wouldn't it work for you?  Just make sure the counterop is secured and insulate the sidewalls (will help them be more forgiving and shock absorbing).  Oh well...I know you guys won't see this...

snippet.textDisplay: What type of batteries are you using? The best battery is a DEEP CYCLE battery or cheaper is a VRLA ,Valve Regulated Lead Acid, with safety valves, (recharging in a confined space, the safety valve reduce the chance of hydro gas explosion when quickly charging, as a spark can cause a major explosion) that is known as a Gel Cell battery, as they can handle fast discharge, a lot of vibration, as they won’t mechanically break down like a lead plate lead acid auto battery will. They can also handle being run flat, as lead plate acid can’t handle being regularly run flat more then 20% and a lot of vibration, as gel cells are what is usually used in this application along with the Deep Cycle batteries for electric vehicles and SOLAR storage.
snippet.textOriginal: What type of batteries are you using? The best battery is a DEEP CYCLE battery or cheaper is a VRLA ,Valve Regulated Lead Acid, with safety valves, (recharging in a confined space, the safety valve reduce the chance of hydro gas explosion when quickly charging, as a spark can cause a major explosion) that is known as a Gel Cell battery, as they can handle fast discharge, a lot of vibration, as they won’t mechanically break down like a lead plate lead acid auto battery will. They can also handle being run flat, as lead plate acid can’t handle being regularly run flat more then 20% and a lot of vibration, as gel cells are what is usually used in this application along with the Deep Cycle batteries for electric vehicles and SOLAR storage.

snippet.textDisplay: Mounting the pannels in series you increase the output voltage, to increase power you have to mount them in parallel as you have done with the batteries
snippet.textOriginal: Mounting the pannels in series you increase the output voltage, to increase power you have to mount them in parallel as you have done with the batteries

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry, another battery comment, get them outside is best,  suitable box with plenty of ventilation, or go lithium(expensive but good). Under the sofa/bed is best for water tank, you don't want that outside to avoid freezing, and anything with weight wants to be low down to preserve centre of gravity as low as possible. Check out bus grease monkey, apart from his massive knowledge of Detroit diesels he's just completed an amazing solar install, well more to come I believe but worth a watch? Great channel by the way, been here a while now👍

snippet.textDisplay: You should definately run all 8 solar panels. just do a mixed series parallel circuit. 2x 4 panels in series, then put those 2 lines in parallel into the mppt charge controller. In series you add the volts but current stays equal to one panel. In parallel you add the current but volts is equal to one panel. not sure the specs of your panels but let's say you have automotive panels rated at 20v and 10A. Formula for total circuit volts and amps would be 4 X 20v = 80v. And 2 X 10A= 20A. So total circuit specs would be 80v at 20A. Usable power stays the same regardless of how you hook the circuit up, so 8 X rated panel watts.  Pm me if you need any help 🙂. Love the build guys, it's gonna be awesome when it's done
snippet.textOriginal: You should definately run all 8 solar panels. just do a mixed series parallel circuit. 2x 4 panels in series, then put those 2 lines in parallel into the mppt charge controller. In series you add the volts but current stays equal to one panel. In parallel you add the current but volts is equal to one panel. not sure the specs of your panels but let's say you have automotive panels rated at 20v and 10A. Formula for total circuit volts and amps would be 4 X 20v = 80v. And 2 X 10A= 20A. So total circuit specs would be 80v at 20A. Usable power stays the same regardless of how you hook the circuit up, so 8 X rated panel watts.  Pm me if you need any help 🙂. Love the build guys, it's gonna be awesome when it's done

snippet.textDisplay: Also, a handy calculation when planning electrical loads. Amps X Volts = Watts. This simple formula will get you a long way.
snippet.textOriginal: Also, a handy calculation when planning electrical loads. Amps X Volts = Watts. This simple formula will get you a long way.

snippet.textDisplay: Guys love what you're doing here. One piece of critical advice. The batteries you selected appear to be traditional lead acid batteries. Lead acid batteries vent hydrogen when they're charging.  Hydrogen is highly explosive and will accumulate in the wood structure under the seats. PLEASE either replace these batteries with AGM batteries that don't vent gases when they charge, this would be ideal. Alternatively,  you could cut a vent to the outside from the battery space but you'd have to ensure its adequate to ensure no accumulation of gases in the interior spaces.
snippet.textOriginal: Guys love what you're doing here. One piece of critical advice. The batteries you selected appear to be traditional lead acid batteries. Lead acid batteries vent hydrogen when they're charging.  Hydrogen is highly explosive and will accumulate in the wood structure under the seats. PLEASE either replace these batteries with AGM batteries that don't vent gases when they charge, this would be ideal. Alternatively,  you could cut a vent to the outside from the battery space but you'd have to ensure its adequate to ensure no accumulation of gases in the interior spaces.
